H0.text: Subtracting atomic number from mass number yields the number of neutrons in an atom.

H1.text: Mass number from atomic number is the quantity subtracted from the atomic number to find the number of neutrons in an atom.

H2.text: Subtracting the atomic number from the electron number gives the number of neutrons in an atom.

H3.text: Isotope number from electron number is subtracted to find the number of neutrons in an atom.

A4.text: Nuclides with the same atomic mass number, but different atomic and neutron numbers, are called isobars.

A5.text: The most common nuclide of the common chemical element lead, 208Pb, has 82 protons and 126 neutrons, for example.
